findings.title: Skill does not specify a license
findings.description: Skill manifest does not include a 'license' field. Specifying a license helps users understand usage terms.
findings.remediation: Add 'license' field to SKILL.md frontmatter (e.g., MIT, Apache-2.0)

findings.title: HTTP client library imports that enable external communication
findings.remediation: Ensure network access is necessary and documented. Review all URLs

findings.title: Reading environment variables that may contain secrets
findings.remediation: Minimize access to environment variables. Document why needed

findings.title: Undeclared network usage
findings.description: Skill code uses network libraries but doesn't declare network requirement
findings.remediation: Declare network usage in compatibility field or remove network calls

findings.title: Missing Optional Metadata Fields
findings.description: The skill's YAML manifest is missing optional metadata fields (license, compatibility, allowed-tools). While these fields are optional per the agent skills specification, their absence reduces transparency about the skill's requirements and constraints. The missing 'allowed-tools' field means users cannot verify which agent tools the skill intends to use.
findings.snippet:
license: Not specified
compatibility: Not specified
allowed-tools: Not specified
findings.remediation:
Add optional metadata fields to improve transparency:
- license: Specify the license (e.g., MIT, Apache-2.0)
- compatibility: Document where the skill works (e.g., 'Claude.ai, Claude Code, API')
- allowed-tools: Declare which tools are used (e.g., [Bash, Python, Read, Write])

metadata.overall_assessment: The hugging-face-tool-builder skill is SAFE with minor documentation gaps. The skill creates reusable command-line scripts for interacting with the Hugging Face API. All scripts follow secure patterns: they use the HF_TOKEN environment variable for authentication (avoiding hardcoded secrets), include proper help documentation, handle errors gracefully, and perform legitimate API operations. The scripts read from internal reference files within the skill package (normal behavior for self-contained skills) and make authenticated API calls to huggingface.co (the legitimate service). No prompt injection, data exfiltration, command injection, or other security threats were detected. The only issue is missing optional metadata fields in the YAML manifest, which is a minor documentation concern rather than a security risk.
